verses.text: Now when an attempt was made by both gentiles and Jews, along with their authorities, to mistreat and stone them,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Paul and Barnabas found out about it and fled to the Lycaonian towns of Lystra and Derbe and to the surrounding territory.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: There they kept talking about the good news.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Now in Lystra there was a man sitting down who couldn’t use his feet. He had been crippled from birth and had never walked.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He was listening to Paul as he spoke. Paul watched him closely, and when he saw that he had faith to be healed,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: he said in a loud voice, “Stand up straight on your feet!” Then the man jumped up and began to walk.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When the crowds saw what Paul had done, they shouted in the Lycaonian language, “The gods have become like men and have come down to us!”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They began to call Barnabas Zeus, and Paul Hermes, because he was the main speaker.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The priest of the temple of Zeus, which was just outside the city, brought bulls and garlands to the gates. He and the crowds wanted to offer sacrifices.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But when the apostles Barnabas and Paul heard of it, they tore their clothes and rushed out into the crowd, shouting,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Men, why are you doing this? We are merely human beings with natures like yours. We are telling you the good news so you’ll turn from these worthless things to the living God, who made heaven and earth, the sea, and everything in them.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: In past generations he allowed all the nations to go their own ways,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: yet he has not abandoned his witness: he continues to do good, to give you rain from heaven, to give you fruitful seasons, and to fill you with food and your hearts with joy.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Even by saying this, it was all Paul and Barnabas could do to keep the crowds from offering sacrifices to them.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But some Jews came from Antioch and Iconium and won over the crowds by persuasion. They stoned Paul and dragged him out of the town, thinking he was dead.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But the disciples formed a circle around him, and he got up and went back to town. The next day, he went on with Barnabas to Derbe.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: As they were proclaiming the good news in that city, they discipled a large number of people. Then they went back to Lystra, Iconium, and Antioch,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: strengthening the disciples and encouraging them to continue in the faith. “We must endure many hardships,” they said, “to get into the kingdom of God.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Paul and Barnabas appointed elders for them in each church, and with prayer and fasting they entrusted them to the Lord in whom they had believed.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then they passed through Pisidia and came to Pamphylia.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They spoke the word in Perga and went down to Attalia.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: From there they sailed back to Antioch, where they had been entrusted to the grace of God for the work they had completed.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When they arrived, they called the church together and told them everything that God had done with them and how he had opened a door so that gentiles would believe.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then they spent a long time with the disciples.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then some men came down from Judea and started to teach the brothers, “Unless you are circumcised according to the Law of Moses, you can’t be saved.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Paul and Barnabas had quite a dispute and argument with them. So Paul and Barnabas and some of the others were appointed to go up to Jerusalem to confer with the apostles and elders about this question.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They were sent on their way by the church, and as they were going through Phoenicia and Samaria they told of the conversion of the gentiles and brought great joy to all the brothers.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When they arrived in Jerusalem, they were welcomed by the church, the apostles, and the elders, and they reported everything that God had done through them.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But some believers from the party of the Pharisees stood up and said, “The gentiles must be circumcised and ordered to keep the Law of Moses.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So the apostles and the elders met to look into this claim.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: After a lengthy debate, Peter stood up and told them, “Brothers, you know that in the early days, God chose me to be the one among you through whom the gentiles would hear the message of the gospel and believe.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: God, who knows everyone’s heart, showed them he approved by giving them the Holy Spirit, just as he did to us.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He made no distinction between them and us, because of their faith-cleansed hearts.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So why do you test God by putting on the disciples’ neck a yoke that neither our ancestors nor we could carry?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: We certainly believe that it is through the grace of the Lord Jesus, the Messiah, that we are saved, just as they are.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The whole crowd was silent as they listened to Barnabas and Paul tell about all the signs and wonders that God had done through them among the gentiles.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: After Paul and Barnabas had finished speaking, James responded, “Brothers, listen to me:
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Simeon has explained how God first showed his concern for the gentiles by taking from among them a people for his name.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: This agrees with the words of the prophets. As it is written,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
‘“After this, I will come back
    and set up David’s fallen tent again.
I will restore its ruined places
    and set it up again
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
so that the rest of the people may search for the Lord,
    including all the gentiles who are called by my name,’
        declares the Lord.
‘He is the one who has been doing these things
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: that have been known from long ago.’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Therefore, I have decided that we should not trouble these gentiles who are turning to God.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Instead, we should write to them to keep away from things polluted by idols, from sexual immorality, from anything strangled, and from blood.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: After all, Moses has had people to proclaim him in every city for generations, and on every Sabbath his books are read aloud in the synagogues.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then the apostles, the elders, and the whole church decided to choose some of their men to send with Paul and Barnabas to Antioch. These were Judas, who was called Barsabbas, and Silas, who were leaders among the brothers.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
They wrote this letter for them to deliver:
“From: The apostles and the elders, your brothers
To: Their gentile brothers in Antioch, Syria, and Cilicia.
Greetings.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: We have heard that some men, coming from us without instructions from us, have said things to trouble you and have unsettled you.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So we have unanimously decided to choose men and send them to you with our dear Barnabas and Paul,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: who have risked their lives for the sake of our Lord Jesus, the Messiah.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: We have therefore sent Judas and Silas to tell you the same things by word of mouth.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: For it seemed good to the Holy Spirit and to us not to place on you any burden but these essential requirements:
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: to keep away from food sacrificed to idols, from blood, from anything strangled, and from sexual immorality. If you avoid these things, you will do well. Goodbye.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So the men were sent on their way and arrived in Antioch. They gathered the congregation together and delivered the letter.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When the people read it, they were pleased with how the letter encouraged them.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Judas and Silas, who were also prophets, said a lot to encourage and strengthen the brothers.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: After staying there for some time, they were sent back with a greeting from the brothers to those who had sent them.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Both Paul and Barnabas remained in Antioch to teach and proclaim the word of the Lord, as did many others.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: A few days later, Paul told Barnabas, “Let’s go back and visit the brothers in every town where we proclaimed the word of the Lord and see how they’re doing.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Barnabas wanted to take along John, who was called Mark,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: but Paul did not think it was right to take along the man who had deserted them in Pamphylia and who had not gone with them into the work.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The disagreement was so sharp that they parted ways. Barnabas took Mark and sailed to Cyprus,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: while Paul chose Silas and left after the brothers had entrusted him to the grace of the Lord.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He went through Syria and Cilicia and strengthened the churches.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Paul also went to Derbe and Lystra, where there was a disciple named Timothy, the son of a believing Jewish wife whose husband was a Greek.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Timothy was highly regarded by the brothers in Lystra and Iconium.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Paul wanted this man to go with him, so he took him and had him circumcised because of the Jews who lived in that region, since everyone knew that Timothy’s father was a Greek.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: As they went from town to town, they delivered the decisions reached by the apostles and elders in Jerusalem for them to obey.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So the churches continued to be strengthened in the faith and to increase in numbers every day.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Because they had been prevented by the Holy Spirit from speaking the word in Asia, Paul and Timothy went through the region of Phrygia and Galatia.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They went as far as Mysia and tried to enter Bithynia, but the Spirit of Jesus did not permit them,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: so they bypassed Mysia and went down to Troas.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: During the night Paul had a vision. A man from Macedonia was standing there and pleading with him, “Come over to Macedonia and help us!”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: As soon as he had seen the vision, we immediately looked for a way to go to Macedonia, because we were convinced that God had called us to tell the people there the good news.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Sailing from Troas, we went straight to Samothrace, the next day to Neapolis,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: and from there to Philippi, an important city of the district of Macedonia and a Roman colony. We were in this city for several days.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: On the Sabbath day, we went out the city gate and walked along the river, where we thought there was a place of prayer. We sat down and began talking to the women who had gathered there.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: A woman named Lydia, from the city of Thyatira, a dealer in purple goods, was listening to us. She was a worshiper of God, and the Lord opened her heart to listen carefully to what was being said by Paul.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When she and her family were baptized, she urged us, “If you are convinced that I am a believer in the Lord, come and stay at my home.” And she continued to insist that we do so.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Once, as we were going to the place of prayer, we met a slave girl who had a spirit of fortune-telling and who had brought her owners a great deal of money by predicting the future.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: She would follow Paul and us and shout, “These men are servants of the Most High God and are proclaiming to you a way of salvation!”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: She kept doing this for many days until Paul became annoyed, turned to her and told the spirit, “I command you in the name of Jesus the Messiah to come out of her!” And it came out that very moment.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When her owners realized that their hope of making money was gone, they grabbed Paul and Silas and dragged them before the authorities who met together in the public square.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They brought them before the magistrates and said, “These men are stirring up a lot of trouble in our city. They are Jews
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: and are advocating customs that we’re not allowed to accept or practice as Romans.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The crowd joined in the attack against them. Then the magistrates had Paul and Silas stripped of their clothes and ordered them beaten with rods.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: After giving them a severe beating, they threw them in jail and ordered the jailer to keep them under tight security.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Having received these orders, he put them into the inner cell and fastened their feet in leg irons.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Around midnight, Paul and Silas were praying and singing hymns to God, and the other prisoners were listening to them.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Suddenly, there was an earthquake so violent that the foundations of the prison were shaken. All the doors immediately flew open, and everyone’s chains were unfastened.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When the jailer woke up and saw the prison doors wide open, he drew his sword and was about to kill himself, since he thought the prisoners had escaped.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But Paul shouted in a loud voice, “Don’t hurt yourself, because we are all here!”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The jailer asked for torches and rushed inside. Trembling as he knelt in front of Paul and Silas,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: he took them outside and asked, “Sirs, what must I do to be saved?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They answered, “Believe on the Lord Jesus, and you and your family will be saved.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then they spoke the word of the Lord to him and everyone in his home.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: At that hour of the night, he took them and washed their wounds. Then he and his entire family were baptized immediately.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He brought Paul and Silas upstairs into his house and set food before them. He was thrilled, as was his household, to believe in God.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When day came, the magistrates sent guards, who commanded, “Release those men.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The jailer reported these words to Paul, and added, “The magistrates have sent word to release you. So come out now and go in peace.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But Paul told the guards, “The magistrates have had us beaten publicly without a trial and have thrown us into jail, even though we are Roman citizens. Now are they going to throw us out secretly? Certainly not! Have them come and escort us out.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The guards reported these words to the magistrates, and they became afraid when they heard that Paul and Silas were Roman citizens.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So the magistrates came, apologized to them, and escorted them out. Then they asked them to leave the city.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Leaving the jail, Paul and Silas went to Lydia’s house. They saw the brothers, encouraged them, and then left.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Paul and Silas traveled through Amphipolis and Apollonia and came to Thessalonica, where there was a Jewish synagogue.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: As usual, Paul entered there and on three Sabbaths discussed the Scriptures with them.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He explained and showed them that the Messiah had to suffer and rise from the dead: “This very Jesus whom I proclaim to you is the Messiah.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Some of them were persuaded and began to be associated with Paul and Silas, especially a large crowd of devout Greeks and the wives of many prominent men.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But the Jewish leaders became jealous, and they took some contemptible characters who used to hang out in the public square, formed a mob, and started a riot in the city. They attacked Jason’s home and searched it for Paul and Silas in order to bring them out to the people.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When they didn’t find them, they dragged Jason and some other brothers before the city officials and shouted, “These fellows who have turned the world upside down have come here, too,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: and Jason has welcomed them as his guests. All of them oppose the emperor’s decrees by saying that there is another king—Jesus!”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The crowd and the city officials were upset when they heard this,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: but after they had gotten a bond from Jason and the others, they let them go.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: That night the brothers immediately sent Paul and Silas away to Berea. When they arrived, they went into the Jewish synagogue.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: These people were more receptive than those in Thessalonica. They were very willing to receive the message, and every day they carefully examined the Scriptures to see if those things were so.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Many of them believed, including a large number of prominent Greek women and men.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But when the Jewish leaders in Thessalonica found out that the word of God had been proclaimed by Paul also in Berea, they went there to upset and incite the crowds.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then the brothers immediately sent Paul away to the coast, but Silas and Timothy stayed there.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The men who escorted Paul took him all the way to Athens and, after receiving instructions to have Silas and Timothy join him as soon as possible, they left.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: While Paul was waiting for them in Athens, his spirit was deeply disturbed to see the city full of idols.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So he began holding discussions in the synagogue with the Jews and other worshipers, as well as every day in the public square with anyone who happened to be there.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Some Epicurean and Stoic philosophers also debated with him. Some asked, “What is this blabbermouth trying to say?” while others said, “He seems to be preaching about foreign gods.” This was because Paul was telling the good news about Jesus and the resurrection.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then they took him, brought him before the Areopagus, and asked, “May we know what this new teaching of yours is?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: It sounds rather strange to our ears, and we would like to know what it means.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Now all the Athenians and the foreigners living there used to spend their time doing nothing else other than listening to the latest ideas or repeating them.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So Paul stood up in front of the Areopagus and said, “Men of Athens, I see that you are very religious in every way.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: For as I was walking around and looking closely at the objects you worship, I even found an altar with this written on it: ‘To an unknown god.’ So I am telling you about the unknown object you worship.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The God who made the world and everything in it is the Lord of heaven and earth. He doesn’t live in shrines made by human hands,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: and he isn’t served by people as if he needed anything. He himself gives everyone life, breath, and everything else.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: From one man he made every nation of humanity to live all over the earth, fixing the seasons of the year and the national boundaries within which they live,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: so that they might look for God, somehow reach for him, and find him. Of course, he is never far from any one of us.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: For we live, move, and exist because of him, as some of your own poets have said: ‘…Since we are his children, too.’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So if we are God’s children, we shouldn’t think that the divine being is like gold, silver, or stone, or is an image carved by humans using their own imagination and skill.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Though God has overlooked those times of ignorance, he now commands everyone everywhere to repent,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: because he has set a day when he is going to judge the world with justice through a man whom he has appointed. He has given proof of this to everyone by raising him from the dead.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When they heard about a resurrection of the dead, some began joking about it, while others said, “We will hear you again about this.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And so Paul left the meeting.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Some men joined him and became believers. With them were Dionysius, who was a member of the Areopagus, a woman named Damaris, and some others along with them.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: After this, Paul left Athens and went to Corinth.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: There he found a Jew named Aquila, a native of Pontus, who had recently come from Italy with his wife Priscilla because Claudius had ordered all the Jews to leave Rome. Paul went to visit them,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: and because they had the same trade he stayed with them. They worked together because they were tentmakers by trade.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Every Sabbath, he would speak in the synagogue, trying to persuade both Jews and Greeks.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But when Silas and Timothy arrived from Macedonia, Paul devoted himself entirely to the word as he emphatically assured the Jews that Jesus is the Messiah.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But when they began to oppose him and insult him, he shook out his clothes in protest and told them, “Your blood be on your own heads! I am innocent. From now on I will go to the gentiles.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then he left that place and went to the home of a man named Titius Justus, who worshipped God and whose house was next door to the synagogue.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Now Crispus, the leader of the synagogue, believed in the Lord, along with his whole family. Many Corinthians who heard Paul also believed and were baptized.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: One night, the Lord told Paul in a vision, “Stop being afraid to speak out! Don’t remain silent!
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: For I am with you, and no one will lay a hand on you or harm you, because I have many people in this city.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So Paul lived there for a year and a half and continued to teach the word of God among the people there.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: While Gallio was proconsul of Achaia, the Jewish leaders gathered together, attacked Paul, and brought him before the judge’s seat.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They said, “This man is persuading people to worship God in ways that are contrary to the Law.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Paul was about to speak when Gallio admonished the Jewish leaders, “If there were some misdemeanor or crime involved, it would be reasonable to put up with you Jews.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But since it is a question about words, names, and your own Law, you will have to take care of that yourselves. I refuse to be a judge in these matters.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So he drove them away from the judge’s seat.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then all of them took Sosthenes, the synagogue leader, and began beating him in front of the judge’s seat. But Gallio paid no attention to any of this.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: After staying there for quite a while longer, Paul said goodbye to the brothers and sailed for Syria, accompanied by Priscilla and Aquila. He had his hair cut in Cenchrea, since he was under a vow.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When they arrived in Ephesus, he left Priscilla and Aquila there. Then he went into the synagogue and had a discussion with the Jews.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They asked him to stay longer, but he refused.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: As he told them goodbye, he said, “I will come back to you again if it is God’s will.” Then he set sail from Ephesus.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When he arrived in Caesarea, he went up to Jerusalem, greeted the church there, and then returned to Antioch.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: After spending some time there, he departed and went from place to place through the region of Galatia and Phrygia, strengthening all the disciples.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Meanwhile, a Jew named Apollos arrived in Ephesus. He was a native of Alexandria, an eloquent man, and well versed in the Scriptures.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He had been instructed in the Lord’s way, and with spiritual fervor he kept speaking and teaching accurately about Jesus, although he knew only about John’s baptism.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He began to speak boldly in the synagogue, but when Priscilla and Aquila heard him, they took him home and explained God’s way to him more accurately.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When Apollos wanted to cross over to Achaia, the brothers wrote to the disciples there, urging them to welcome him. On his arrival he greatly helped those who, through God’s grace, had believed.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He successfully refuted the Jews in public and proved by the Scriptures that Jesus is the Messiah.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: It was while Apollos was in Corinth that Paul passed through the inland districts and came to Ephesus. He found a few disciples there
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
and asked them, “Did you receive the Holy Spirit when you believed?”
They answered him, “No, we haven’t even heard that there is a Holy Spirit.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
He then asked, “Then into what were you baptized?”
They answered, “Into John’s baptism.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Paul said, “John baptized when they repented, telling the people to believe in the one who was to come after him, that is, in Jesus.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: On hearing this, they were baptized in the name of the Lord Jesus.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When Paul laid his hands on them, the Holy Spirit came on them, and they began to speak in foreign languages and to prophesy.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: There were about twelve men in all.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He went into the synagogue and spoke there boldly for three months, holding discussions and persuading those who heard him about the kingdom of God.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But when some people became stubborn, refused to believe, and slandered the Way in front of the people, Paul left them, taking his disciples away with him, and held daily discussions in the lecture hall of Tyrannus.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: This went on for two years, so that all who lived in Asia, Jews and Greeks alike, heard the word of the Lord.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: God continued to do extraordinary miracles through Paul.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When handkerchiefs and aprons that had touched his skin were taken to the sick, their diseases left them and evil spirits went out of them.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then some Jews who went around trying to drive out demons attempted to use the name of the Lord Jesus on those who had evil spirits, saying, “I command you by that Jesus whom Paul preaches!”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Seven sons of a Jewish high priest named Sceva were doing this.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But the evil spirit told them, “Jesus I know, and I am getting acquainted with Paul, but who are you?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then the man with the evil spirit jumped on them, got the better of them, and so violently overpowered all of them that they fled out of the house naked and bruised.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When this became known to everyone living in Ephesus, Jews and Greeks alike, they all became terrified, and the name of the Lord Jesus began to be held in high honor.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Many who became believers kept coming to confess and talk about what they had been doing.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Moreover, many people who had practiced occult arts gathered their books and burned them in front of everybody. They estimated their value and found them to have been worth 50,000 silver coins.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: In that way the word of the Lord kept spreading and triumphing.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: After these things had happened, Paul decided to go through Macedonia and Achaia and then to go on to Jerusalem. “After I have gone there,” he told them, “I must also see Rome.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then he sent two of his helpers, Timothy and Erastus, to Macedonia, while he himself stayed in Asia a while longer.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Now about that time a great commotion broke out concerning the Way.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: By making silver shrines of Artemis, a silversmith named Demetrius provided a large income for skilled workers.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He called a meeting of these men and others who were engaged in similar trades and said, “Men, you well know that we get a good income from this business.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: You also see and hear that, not only in Ephesus, but almost all over Asia, this man Paul has won over and taken away a large crowd by telling them that gods made by human hands are not gods at all.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: There is a danger not only that our business will lose its reputation but also that the temple of the great goddess Artemis will be brought into disrepute and that she will be robbed of her majesty that brought all Asia and the world to worship her.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When they heard this, they became furious and began to shout, “Great is Artemis of the Ephesians!”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The city was filled with confusion, and the people rushed into the theater together, dragging with them Gaius and Aristarchus, Paul’s fellow travelers from Macedonia.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Paul wanted to go into the crowd, but the disciples wouldn’t let him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Even some officials of the province of Asia who were his friends sent him a message urging him not to risk his life in the theater.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Meanwhile, some were shouting one thing and some another, since the crowd was confused, and most of them didn’t know why they were meeting.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Some of the crowd concluded it was because of Alexander, since the Jews had pushed him to the front. So Alexander motioned for silence and tried to make a defense before the people.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But when they found out that he was a Jew, they all started to shout in unison for about two hours, “Great is Artemis of the Ephesians!”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When the city recorder had quieted the crowd, he said, “Men of Ephesus, who in the world doesn’t know that this city of Ephesus is the keeper of the temple of the great Artemis and of the statue that fell down from heaven?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Since these things cannot be denied, you must be quiet and not do anything reckless.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: For you have brought these men here, although they neither rob temples nor blaspheme our goddess.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So if Demetrius and his workers have a charge against anyone, the courts are open and there are proconsuls. They should accuse one another there.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But if you want anything else, it must be settled in the regular assembly,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: because we are in danger of being charged with rioting today, and there is no good reason we can give to justify this commotion.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: After saying this, he dismissed the assembly.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When the uproar was over, Paul sent for the disciples and encouraged them. Then he said goodbye to them and left to go to Macedonia.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He went through those regions and encouraged the people with everything he had to say. Then he went to Greece
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: and stayed there for three months. When he was about to sail for Syria, a plot was initiated against him by the Jews, so he decided to go back through Macedonia.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He was accompanied by Sopater (the son of Pyrrhus) from Berea, Aristarchus and Secundus from Thessalonica, Gaius from Derbe, Timothy, and Tychicus and Trophimus from Asia.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: These men went on ahead and were waiting for us in Troas.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: After the Festival of Unleavened Bread, we sailed from Philippi, and days later we joined them in Troas and stayed there for seven days.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: On the first day of the week, when we had met to break bread, Paul began to address the people. Since he intended to leave the next day, he went on speaking until midnight.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Now there were many lamps in the upstairs room where we were meeting.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: A young man named Eutychus, who was sitting in a window, began to sink off into a deep sleep as Paul kept speaking longer and longer. Overcome by sleep, he fell down from the third floor and was picked up dead.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But Paul went down, bent over him, took him into his arms, and said, “Stop being alarmed, because he’s still alive.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then he went back upstairs, broke bread, and ate. He talked with them for a long time, until dawn, and then left.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They took the young man away alive and were greatly relieved.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: We proceeded to the ship and sailed for Assos, where we intended to pick up Paul. He had arranged it this way, since he had planned to travel there on foot.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When he met us in Assos, we took him on board and went to Mitylene.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: We sailed from there and on the following day arrived off Chios. The next day, we crossed over to Samos and stayed at Trogyllium. The day after that, we came to Miletus.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Paul had decided to sail past Ephesus to avoid spending time in Asia, as he was in a hurry to get to Jerusalem for the day of Pentecost, if that was possible.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: From Miletus he sent messengers to Ephesus to ask the elders of the church to meet with him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When they came to him, he told them, “You know how I lived among you the entire time from the first day I set foot in Asia.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I served the Lord with all humility, with tears, and with trials that came to me through the plots of the Jews.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I never shrank from telling you anything that would help you nor from teaching you publicly and from house to house.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I testified to both Jews and Greeks about repentance to God and faith in our Lord Jesus.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And now, compelled by the Spirit, I am on my way to Jerusalem, not knowing what will happen to me there,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: except that in town after town the Holy Spirit assures me that imprisonment and suffering are waiting for me.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But I don’t place any value on my life, if only I can finish my race and the ministry that I received from the Lord Jesus of testifying to the gospel of God’s grace.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Now I know that none of you among whom I traveled preaching about the kingdom will ever see my face again.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I therefore declare to you today that I’m not responsible for the blood of any of you,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: because I never shrank from telling you the whole plan of God.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Pay attention to yourselves and to the entire flock over which the Holy Spirit has made you overseers to be shepherds of God’s church, which he acquired with his own blood.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I know that when I’m gone, savage wolves will come among you and not spare the flock.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Indeed, some of your own men will arise and distort the truth in order to lure the disciples into following them.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So be alert! Remember that for three years, night and day, I never stopped tearfully warning each of you.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “I’m now entrusting you to God and to the message of his grace, which is able to build you up and secure for you an inheritance among all who are sanctified.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I never desired anyone’s silver, gold, or clothes.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: You yourselves know that I worked with my own hands to support myself and those who were with me.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: In every way I showed you that by working hard like this we should help the weak and remember the words that the Lord Jesus himself said, ‘It is more blessed to give than to receive.’”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When Paul had said this, he knelt down and prayed with all of them.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: All of them cried and cried as they put their arms around Paul and kissed him affectionately.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They were especially sorrowful because of what he had said—that they would never see his face again. Then they took him to the ship.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When we had torn ourselves away from those brothers, we sailed straight to Cos, and the next day to Rhodes, and from there to Patara.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: There we found a ship going across to Phoenicia, so we went aboard and sailed on.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: We came in sight of Cyprus, and leaving it on our left, we sailed on to Syria and landed at Tyre because the ship was to unload its cargo there.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So we located some disciples and stayed there for seven days. Through the Spirit, they kept telling Paul not to go to Jerusalem,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: but when our time there came to an end, we left and proceeded on our journey. All of them accompanied us with their wives and children out of the city. We knelt on the beach, prayed,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: and said goodbye to each other. Then we reboarded the ship, and they went back home.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When we completed our voyage from Tyre, we arrived at Ptolemais, greeted the brothers there, and stayed with them for one day.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The next day, we left and came to Caesarea. We went to the home of Philip the evangelist, one of the Seven, and stayed with him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He had four unmarried daughters who could prophesy.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: After we had been there for a number of days, a prophet named Agabus arrived from Judea.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He came to us, took Paul’s belt, and tied his own feet and hands with it. Then he said, “The Holy Spirit says, ‘This is how the Jewish leaders in Jerusalem will tie up the man who owns this belt. Then they will hand him over to the gentiles.’”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When we heard this, we and the people who lived there begged Paul not to go up to Jerusalem.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: At this Paul replied, “What do you mean by crying and breaking my heart? I’m ready not only to be tied up in Jerusalem but even to die for the name of the Lord Jesus!”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When he could not be persuaded otherwise, we remained silent except to say, “May the Lord’s will be done.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When our time there ended, we got ready to go up to Jerusalem.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Some of the disciples from Caesarea went with us. They took us to the home of Mnason to be his guests. He was from Cyprus and had been an early disciple.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When we arrived in Jerusalem, the brothers there welcomed us warmly.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The next day, Paul went with us to visit James, and all the elders were present.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: After greeting them, Paul related one by one the things that God had done among the gentiles through his ministry.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When they heard about it, they praised God and told him, “You see, brother, how many tens of thousands of believers there are among the Jews, and all of them are zealous for the Law.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But they have been told about you—that you teach all the Jews living among the gentiles to forsake the Law of Moses, and that you tell them not to circumcise their children or observe the customs.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: What is to be done? They will certainly hear that you have come.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So do what we tell you. We have four men who are under a vow.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Take these men, go through the purification ceremony with them, and pay their expenses to shave their heads. Then everyone will know that there is nothing in what they have been told about you, but that you are carefully observing and keeping the Law.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: As for the gentiles who have become believers, we have sent a letter with our decision that they should keep away from food that has been sacrificed to idols, from blood, from anything strangled, and from sexual immorality.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Paul took those men and the next day purified himself with them. Then he went into the Temple to announce the time when their days of purification would end and when the sacrifice would be offered for each of them.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When the seven days were almost over, the Jews from Asia, seeing Paul in the Temple, stirred up a large crowd. They grabbed Paul,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: yelling, “Men of Israel, help! This is the man who teaches everyone everywhere to turn against our people, the Law, and this place. More than that, he has even brought Greeks into the Temple and desecrated this Holy Place.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: For they had earlier seen Trophimus the Ephesian in the city with him and assumed that Paul had taken him into the Temple.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The whole city was in chaos. The people rushed together, grabbed Paul, dragged him out of the Temple, and at once the doors were sealed shut.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The crowd was trying to kill Paul when a report reached the tribune of the cohort that all Jerusalem was in an uproar.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Immediately the tribune took some soldiers and officers and ran down to the crowd. When the people saw the tribune and the soldiers, they stopped beating Paul.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then the tribune came up, grabbed Paul, and ordered him to be tied up with two chains. He then asked who Paul was and what he had done.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Some of the crowd shouted this and some that. Since the tribune couldn’t learn the facts due to the confusion, he ordered Paul to be taken into the barracks.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When Paul got to the steps, he had to be carried by the soldiers because the mob had become so violent.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The crowd of people kept following him and shouting, “Kill him!”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Just as Paul was about to be taken into the barracks, he asked the tribune, “May I say something to you?”
The tribune asked, “Oh, do you speak Greek?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: You’re not the Egyptian who started a revolt some time ago and led 4,000 assassins into the desert, are you?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Paul replied, “I’m a Jew from Tarsus in Cilicia, a citizen of no insignificant city. Please let me speak to the people.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The tribune gave him permission, and Paul, standing on the steps, motioned for the people to be silent. When everyone had quieted down, he spoke to them in the Hebrew language:
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Brothers and fathers, listen to the defense that I am now making before you.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When they heard him speaking to them in Hebrew, they became even more quiet, and he continued:
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “I am a Jew, born in Tarsus in Cilicia but raised in this city and educated at the feet of Gamaliel in the strict ways of our ancestral Law. I am as zealous for God as all of you are today.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I persecuted this Way, even executing people, and kept tying up both men and women and putting them in prison,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: as the high priest and the whole council of elders can testify about me. I also received letters from them to the brothers in Damascus, and I was going there to tie up those who were there and bring them back to Jerusalem to be punished.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “But while I was on my way and approaching Damascus about noon, a bright light from heaven suddenly flashed around me.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I fell to the ground and heard a voice saying to me, ‘Saul! Saul! Why are you persecuting me?’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
“I answered, ‘Who are you, Lord?’
“He told me, ‘I’m Jesus from Nazareth, whom you are persecuting.’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The men who were with me saw the light but didn’t understand the voice of the one who was speaking to me.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
“Then I asked, ‘What am I to do, Lord?’
“The Lord told me, ‘Get up and go into Damascus, and there you will be told everything you are destined to do.’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Since I could not see because of the brightness of the light, the men who were with me took me by the hand and led me into Damascus.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “A certain Ananias, who was a devout man with respect to the Law and who was highly regarded by all the Jews living there,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: came to me. He stood beside me and said, ‘Brother Saul, receive your sight!’ At that moment I could see him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Then he said, ‘The God of our ancestors has chosen you to know his will, to see the Righteous One, and to hear his own voice,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: because you will be his witness to all people of what you have seen and heard.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So now, what are you waiting for? Get up, be baptized, and have your sins washed away as you call on his name.’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Then I returned to Jerusalem. While I was praying in the Temple, I fell into a trance
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: and saw the Lord saying to me, ‘Hurry up and get out of Jerusalem at once, because the people won’t accept your testimony about me.’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “I said, ‘Lord, they themselves know that in every synagogue I kept imprisoning and beating those who believe in you.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Even when the blood of your witness Stephen was being shed, I was standing there, approving it and guarding the coats of those who were killing him.’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Then he told me, ‘Go, because I’ll send you far away to the gentiles.’”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Up to this point they listened to him, but then they began to shout, “Away with such a fellow from the earth! He’s not fit to go on living!”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: While they were yelling, tossing their coats around, and throwing dirt into the air,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: the tribune ordered Paul to be taken into the barracks and told the soldiers to beat and question him in order to find out why the people were yelling at him like this.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But when they had tied him up with the straps, Paul asked the centurion who was standing there, “Is it legal for you to whip a Roman citizen who hasn’t been condemned?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When the centurion heard this, he went to the tribune and told him, “What are you doing? This man is a Roman citizen!”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
So the tribune went and asked Paul, “Tell me, are you a Roman citizen?”
“Yes,” he said.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Then the tribune replied, “I paid a lot of money for this citizenship of mine.”
Paul said, “But I was born a citizen.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Immediately those who were about to examine him stepped back, and the tribune was afraid when he found out that Paul was a Roman citizen and that he had tied him up.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The next day, since the tribune wanted to find out exactly what Paul was being accused of by the Jews, he released him and ordered the high priests and the entire Council to meet. Then he brought Paul down and had him stand before them.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Paul looked straight at the Council and said, “Brothers, with a clear conscience I have done my duty before God up to this very day.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then the high priest Ananias ordered the men standing near him to strike him on the mouth.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: At this Paul told him, “God will strike you, you whitewashed wall! How can you sit there and judge me according to the Law, and yet in violation of the Law order me to be struck?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The men standing near him asked, “Do you mean to insult God’s high priest?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Paul answered, “I didn’t realize, brothers, that he is the high priest. After all, it is written, ‘You must not speak evil about a ruler of your people.’”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When Paul saw that some of them were Sadducees and others were Pharisees, he shouted in the Council, “Brothers, I’m a Pharisee and a descendant of Pharisees. I’m on trial concerning the hope that the dead will be resurrected.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: After he said that, an angry quarrel broke out between the Pharisees and the Sadducees, and the assembly was divided,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: because the Sadducees say that there is no resurrection and that there is no such thing as an angel or spirit, but the Pharisees believe in all those things.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: There was a great deal of shouting until some of the scribes who belonged to the party of the Pharisees stood up and argued forcefully, “We find nothing wrong with this man. What if a spirit or an angel has spoken to him?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The quarrel was becoming violent, and the tribune was afraid that they would tear Paul to pieces. So he ordered the soldiers to go down, take him away from them by force, and bring him into the barracks.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: That night the Lord stood near Paul and said, “Have courage! For just as you have testified about me in Jerusalem, you must testify in Rome, too.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: In the morning, the Jewish leaders formed a conspiracy and took an oath not to eat or drink anything before they had killed Paul.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: More than 40 men formed this conspiracy.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They went to the high priests and elders and said, “We have taken a solemn oath not to taste any food before we have killed Paul.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Now then, you and the Council must notify the tribune to bring him down to you on the pretext that you want to look into his case more carefully, but before he arrives we’ll be ready to kill him.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But the son of Paul’s sister heard about the ambush, so he came and got into the barracks and told Paul.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Paul called one of the centurions and said, “Take this young man to the tribune, because he has something to tell him.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So the centurion took him, brought him to the tribune, and said, “The prisoner Paul called me and asked me to bring this young man to you. He has something to tell you.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The tribune took him by the hand, stepped aside to be alone with him, and asked, “What have you got to tell me?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He answered, “The Jewish leaders have agreed to ask you to bring Paul down to the Council tomorrow as though they were going to examine his case more carefully.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Don’t believe them, because more than 40 of them are planning to ambush him. They’ve taken an oath not to eat or drink before they’ve killed him. They are ready now, just waiting for your consent.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The tribune dismissed the young man and ordered him not to tell anyone that he had notified him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then he summoned two centurions and ordered, “Get 200 soldiers ready to leave for Caesarea at nine o’clock tonight, along with 70 mounted soldiers and 200 soldiers with spears.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Provide a mount for Paul to ride, and take him safely to Governor Felix.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He wrote a letter with this message:
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
“From: Claudius Lysias
To: Governor Felix
Greetings, Your Excellency:
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: This man had been seized by the Jews and was about to be killed by them when I went with the guard and rescued him, having learned that he was a Roman citizen.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I wanted to know the exact charge they were making against him, so I had him brought before their Council.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I found that, although he was charged with questions about their Law, there was no charge against him deserving death or imprisonment.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Since a plot against the man has been reported to me, I’m sending him to you at once, and I’ve also ordered his accusers to present their charges against him before you.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So the soldiers, in keeping with their orders, took Paul and brought him by night to Antipatris.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The next day, they let the horsemen ride with Paul while they returned to their barracks.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When these men came to Caesarea, they delivered the letter to the governor and handed Paul over to him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: After reading the letter, the governor asked which province Paul was from. On learning that he was from Cilicia,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: he said, “I will hear your case when your accusers arrive.” Then he ordered Paul to be kept in custody in Herod’s palace.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Five days later, the high priest Ananias arrived with certain elders and Tertullus, an attorney, and they summarized their case against Paul before the governor.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
When Paul had been summoned, Tertullus opened the prosecution by saying:
“Your Excellency Felix, since we are enjoying lasting peace because of you, and since reforms for this nation are being brought about through your foresight,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: we always and everywhere acknowledge it with profound gratitude.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But so as not to detain you any further, I beg you to hear us briefly with your customary graciousness.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: For we have found this man a perfect pest and an agitator among all Jews throughout the world. He is a ringleader in the sect of the Nazarenes
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: and even tried to profane the Temple, but we arrested him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: By examining him for yourself, you will be able to find out from him everything of which we accuse him.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The Jewish leaders supported his accusations by asserting that these things were true.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
When the governor motioned for Paul to speak, he replied:
“Since I know that you have been a judge over this nation for many years, I am pleased to present my defense.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: You can verify for yourself that I went up to worship in Jerusalem no more than twelve days ago.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They never found me debating with anyone in the Temple or stirring up a crowd in the synagogues or throughout the city,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: and they cannot prove to you the charges they are now bringing against me.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: However, I admit to you that in accordance with the Way, which they call a heresy, I worship the God of our ancestors and believe in everything written in the Law and the Prophets.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I have the same hope in God that they themselves cherish—that there is to be a resurrection of the righteous and the wicked.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Therefore, I always do my best to have a clear conscience before God and people.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: After many years, I have come back to my people to bring gifts for the poor and to offer sacrifices.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They found me in the Temple doing these things just as I had completed the purification ceremony. No crowd or noisy mob was present.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But some Jews from Asia were there, and they should be here before you to accuse me if they have anything against me.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Otherwise, these men themselves should tell what wrong they found when I stood before the Council—
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: unless it is for the one thing I shouted as I stood among them: ‘It is for the resurrection of the dead that I am on trial before you today.’”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Felix was rather well informed about the Way, and so he adjourned the trial with the comment, “When Tribune Lysias arrives, I’ll decide your case.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He ordered the centurion to guard Paul but to let him have some freedom and not to keep any of his friends from caring for his needs.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Some days later, Felix arrived with his wife Drusilla, who was Jewish. He sent for Paul and listened to him talk about faith in Jesus the Messiah.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: As Paul talked about righteousness, self-control, and the coming judgment, Felix became afraid and said, “For the present you may go. When I get a chance, I will send for you again.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: At the same time he was hoping to receive a bribe from Paul, and so he would send for him frequently to talk with him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: After two years had passed, Felix was succeeded by Porcius Festus. Since Felix wanted to do the Jews a favor, he left Paul in prison.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Three days after Festus had arrived in the province, he went up from Caesarea to Jerusalem.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The high priests and Jewish leaders informed him of their charges against Paul, urging
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: and asking Festus to have Paul brought to Jerusalem as a favor. They were laying an ambush to kill him on the road.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Festus replied that Paul was being kept in custody at Caesarea and that he himself would be going there soon.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Therefore,” he said, “have your authorities come down with me and present their charges against him there, if there is anything wrong with the man.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Festus stayed with them no more than eight or ten days and then went down to Caesarea. The next day, he sat on the judge’s seat and ordered Paul brought in.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When Paul arrived, the Jewish leaders who had come down from Jerusalem surrounded him and began bringing a number of serious charges against him that they couldn’t prove.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Paul said in his defense, “I have done nothing wrong against the Law of the Jews, or of the Temple, or of the emperor.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Festus, wanting to do the Jewish leaders a favor, asked Paul, “Are you willing to go up to Jerusalem to be tried there before me on these charges?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But Paul said, “I am standing before the emperor’s judgment seat where I ought to be tried. I haven’t done anything wrong to the Jewish leaders, as you know very well.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: If I’m guilty and have done something that deserves death, I’m willing to die. But if there is nothing to their charges against me, no one can hand me over to them as a favor. I appeal to the emperor!”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Festus talked it over with the council and then answered, “To the emperor you have appealed; to the emperor you will go!”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: After several days had passed, King Agrippa and Bernice came to Caesarea to welcome Festus.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Since they were staying there for several days, Festus laid Paul’s case before the king. He said, “There is a man here who was left in prison by Felix.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When I went to Jerusalem, the high priests and the Jewish elders informed me about him and asked me to condemn him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I answered them that it was not the Roman custom to sentence a man to be punished until the accused met his accusers face to face and had an opportunity to defend himself against the charge.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So they came here with me, and the next day without any delay I sat down in the judge’s seat and ordered the man to be brought in.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When his accusers stood up, they didn’t accuse him of any of the crimes I was expecting.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Instead, they had several arguments with him about their own religion and about a certain Jesus who had died—but Paul kept asserting he was alive.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I was puzzled how I should investigate such matters, so I asked if he would like to go to Jerusalem and be tried there for these things.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But Paul appealed his case and asked to be held in prison until the decision of his Majesty. So I ordered him to be held in custody until I could send him to the emperor.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Agrippa told Festus, “I would like to hear the man.”
“Tomorrow,” he said, “you will hear him.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The next day, Agrippa and Bernice arrived with much fanfare and went into the auditorium along with the tribunes and the leading men of the city. At the command of Festus, Paul was brought in.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Festus said, “King Agrippa and all you men who are present with us! You see this man about whom the whole Jewish nation petitioned me, both in Jerusalem and here, shouting that he ought not to live any longer.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I find that he has not done anything deserving of death. But since he has appealed to his Majesty, I have decided to send him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I have nothing reliable to write our Sovereign about him, so I have brought him to all of you, and especially to you, King Agrippa, so that I will have something to write after he is cross-examined.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: For it seems to me absurd to send a prisoner without specifying the charges against him.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Agrippa told Paul, “You have permission to speak for yourself.” So Paul stretched out his hand and began his defense.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “I consider myself fortunate that it is before you, King Agrippa, that I can defend myself today against all the accusations of the Jewish leaders,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: since you are especially familiar with all the Jewish customs and controversies. I beg you, therefore, to listen patiently to me.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: All the Jews know how I lived from the earliest days of my youth with my own people and in Jerusalem.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They have known for a long time, if they would but testify to it, that I lived as a Pharisee, adhering to the standards of our strictest religious party.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “And now I stand here on trial for the hope of the promise made by God to our ancestors.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Our twelve tribes, worshiping day and night with intense devotion, hope to attain it. It is because of this hope, O King, that I am accused by the Jews.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Why is it thought incredible by all of you that God should raise the dead?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Indeed, I myself thought it my duty to take extreme measures against the name of Jesus from Nazareth.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: That is what I did in Jerusalem. I received authority from the high priests and locked many of the saints in prison. And when I cast my vote against them, they were put to death.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I would even punish them frequently in every synagogue and try to make them blaspheme. Raging furiously against them, I would hunt them down even in distant cities.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “That is how I happened to be traveling to Damascus with authority based on a commission from the high priests.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: On the road at noon, O King, I saw a light from heaven that was brighter than the sun. It flashed around me and those who were traveling with me.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “All of us fell to the ground, and I heard a voice asking me in the Hebrew language, ‘Saul! Saul! Why are you persecuting me? It is hurting you to keep on kicking against the cattle prods.’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
“I asked, ‘Who are you, Lord?’
“The Lord answered, ‘I’m Jesus, whom you are persecuting.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But get up and stand on your feet, because I’ve appeared to you for the very purpose of appointing you to be my servant and witness of what you’ve seen and of what I’ll show you.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I’ll continue to rescue you from your people and from the gentiles to whom I’m sending you.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: You will help them understand and turn them from darkness to light and from Satan’s control to God, so that their sins will be forgiven and they will receive a share among those who are sanctified by faith in me.’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “And so, King Agrippa, I was not disobedient to the heavenly vision.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Instead, I first told the people in Damascus and Jerusalem, then all the people in Judea—and after that the gentiles—to repent, turn to God, and perform deeds that are consistent with such repentance.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: For this reason the Jewish leaders grabbed me in the Temple and kept trying to kill me.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I’ve had help from God to this day, and so I stand here to testify to both the powerful and the lowly alike, stating only what the prophets and Moses said would happen—
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: that the Messiah would suffer and be the first to rise from the dead and would bring light both to our people and to the gentiles.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: As he continued his defense, Festus shouted, “You’re out of your mind, Paul! Too much education is driving you crazy!”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But Paul said, “I’m not out of my mind, Your Excellency Festus. I’m reporting what is absolutely true.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Indeed, the king knows about these things, and I can speak to him freely. For I’m certain that none of these things has escaped his notice, since this wasn’t done in a corner.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: King Agrippa, do you believe the prophets? I know you believe them!”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Agrippa asked Paul, “Can you so quickly persuade me to become a Christian?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Paul replied, “Whether quickly or not, I wish to God that not only you but everyone listening to me today would become what I am—except for these chains!”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then the king, the governor, Bernice, and those who were sitting with him got up.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: As they were leaving, they began to say to each other, “This man hasn’t been doing anything to deserve death or imprisonment.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Agrippa told Festus, “This man could have been set free if he hadn’t appealed to the emperor.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When it was decided that we should sail to Italy, Paul and some other prisoners were transferred to a centurion named Julius, who belonged to the emperor’s division.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: After boarding a ship from Adramyttium that was about to sail to the ports on the coast of Asia, we put out to sea. Aristarchus, a Macedonian from Thessalonica, went with us.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The next day, we arrived at Sidon, and Julius treated Paul kindly, allowing him to visit his friends there and to receive any care he needed.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: After putting out from there, we sailed on the sheltered side of Cyprus because the winds were against us.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: We sailed along the sea off Cilicia and Pamphylia and reached Myra in Lycia.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: There the centurion found an Alexandrian ship bound for Italy and put us on it.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: We sailed slowly for a number of days and with difficulty arrived off Cnidus. Then, because the wind was against us, we sailed on the sheltered side of Crete off Cape Salome.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Sailing past it with difficulty, we came to a place called Fair Havens, near the town of Lasea.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Much time had been lost, and because navigation had become dangerous and the day of fasting had already past, Paul began to warn those on the ship,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Men, I see that during this voyage there will be hardship and a heavy loss not only of the cargo and ship, but also of our lives.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But the centurion was persuaded by the pilot and the owner of the ship and not by what Paul said.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Since the harbor was not a good place to spend the winter, most of the men favored putting out to sea from there on the chance that somehow they could reach Phoenix and spend the winter there. It is a Cretian harbor that faces southwest and northwest.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When a gentle breeze began to blow from the south, they thought they could make it to Phoenix, so they hoisted anchor and began sailing along the shore of Crete.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But it was not long before a violent wind (called a northeaster) swept down from the island.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The ship was caught so that it couldn’t face the wind, and we gave up and were swept along.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: As we drifted to the sheltered side of a small island called Cauda, we barely managed to secure the ship’s lifeboat.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The ship’s crew pulled it up on deck and used ropes to brace the ship. Fearing that they would hit the large sandbank near Libya, they lowered the sail and drifted along.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The next day, because we were being tossed so violently by the storm, they began to throw the cargo overboard.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: On the third day they threw the ship’s equipment overboard with their own hands.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: For a number of days neither the sun nor the stars were to be seen, and the storm continued to rage until at last all hope of our being saved vanished.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: After they had gone a long time without food, Paul stood among his shipmates and said, “Men, you should have listened to me and not have sailed from Crete. You would have avoided this hardship and damage.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But now I urge you to have courage, because there will be no loss of life among you, but only loss of the ship.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: For just last night an angel of God, to whom I belong and whom I serve, stood by me
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: and said, ‘Stop being afraid, Paul! You must stand before the emperor. Indeed, God has given to you the lives of everyone who is sailing with you.’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So take courage, men, because I trust God that it will turn out just as he told me.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: However, we will have to run aground on some island.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: It was the fourteenth night, and we were drifting through the Adriatic Sea, when about midnight the sailors suspected that land was near.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: After taking soundings, they found the depth to be twenty fathoms. A little later, they took soundings again and found it was fifteen fathoms.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Fearing that we might run aground on the rocks, they dropped four anchors from the stern and began praying for daylight to come.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Meanwhile, the sailors had begun trying to escape from the ship. They lowered the lifeboat into the sea and pretended that they were going to lay out the anchors from the bow.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Paul told the centurion and the soldiers, “Unless these men remain onboard, you cannot be saved.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then the soldiers cut the ropes that held the lifeboat and set it adrift.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Right up to daybreak Paul kept urging all of them to eat something. He said, “Today is the fourteenth day that you have been waiting and going without food, not eating anything.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So I urge you to eat something, for it will help you survive, since none of you will lose so much as a hair from his head.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: After he said this, he took some bread, thanked God in front of everyone, broke it, and began to eat.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Everyone was encouraged and had something to eat.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: There were 276 of us on the ship.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: After they had eaten all they wanted, they began to lighten the ship by dumping its cargo of wheat into the sea.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When day came, they didn’t recognize the land, but they could see a bay with a beach on which they planned to run the ship ashore, if possible.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So they cut the anchors free and left them in the sea. At the same time they untied the ropes that held the steering oars, raised the foresail to the wind, and headed for the beach.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But they struck a sandbar and ran the ship aground. The bow stuck and couldn’t be moved, while the stern was broken to pieces by the force of the waves.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The soldiers’ plan was to kill the prisoners to keep them from swimming ashore and escaping,
verses.speaker: Narrator
