verses.text: but the centurion wanted to save Paul, so he prevented them from carrying out their plan. He ordered those who could swim to jump overboard first and get to land.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The rest were to follow, some on planks and others on various pieces of the ship. In this way everyone got to shore safely.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When we were safely on shore, we learned that the island was called Malta.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The people who lived there were unusually kind to us. It had started to rain and was cold, so they started a bonfire and invited us to join them around it.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Paul gathered a bundle of sticks and put it on the fire. A poisonous snake was forced out by the heat and attached itself to Paul’s hand.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When the people who lived there saw the snake hanging from his hand, they told one another, “This man must be a murderer! He may have escaped from the sea, but Justice won’t let him live.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But he shook the snake into the fire and wasn’t harmed.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They were expecting him to swell up or suddenly drop dead, but after waiting a long time and seeing nothing unusual happen to him, they changed their minds and said he was a god.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The governor of the island, whose name was Publius, owned estates in that part of the island. He welcomed us and entertained us with great hospitality for three days.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The father of Publius happened to be sick in bed with fever and dysentery. Paul went to him, prayed, and healed him by placing his hands on him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: After that had happened, the rest of the sick people on the island went to him and were healed.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The islanders honored us in many ways, and when we were about to sail again, they supplied us with everything we needed.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Three months later, we continued our sailing onboard an Alexandrian ship that had spent the winter at the island. It had the Twin Brothers as its figurehead.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: We stopped at Syracuse and stayed there for three days.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then we weighed anchor and came to Rhegium. A day later, a south wind began to blow, and on the second day we came to Puteoli.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: There we found some brothers and were invited to stay with them for seven days. After this, we arrived in Rome.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The brothers there heard about us and came as far as the Forum of Appius and the Three Taverns to meet us. When Paul saw them, he thanked God and felt encouraged.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When we came into Rome, Paul was allowed to live by himself with the soldier who was guarding him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Three days later, Paul called the leaders of the Jews together. When they assembled, he told them, “Brothers, although I haven’t done anything against our people or the customs of our ancestors, I was arrested in Jerusalem and handed over to the Romans.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They examined me and wanted to let me go because there was no reason for me to receive the death penalty in my case.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But the Jews objected and forced me to appeal to the emperor, even though I have no countercharge to bring against my own people.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: That’s why I asked to see you and speak with you, since it is for the hope of Israel that I’m wearing this chain.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The Jewish leaders told him, “We haven’t received any letters from Judea about you, and none of the brothers coming here has reported or mentioned anything bad about you.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: However, we’d like to hear from you what you believe, because people are talking against this sect everywhere.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
So they set a day to meet with Paul and came out in large numbers to see him where he was staying.
From morning until evening, he continued to explain the kingdom of God to them, trying to convince them about Jesus from the Law of Moses and the Prophets.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Some of them were convinced by what he said, but others wouldn’t believe.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They disagreed with one another as they were leaving, so Paul added this statement: “The Holy Spirit was so right when he spoke to your ancestors through the prophet Isaiah!
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
He said,
‘Go to this people and say,
    “You will listen and listen
        but never understand,
    and you will look and look
        but never see!
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
For this people’s minds have become stupid,
    and their ears can barely hear,
and they have shut their eyes
    so that they may never see with their eyes,
and listen with their ears,
    and understand with their heart
and turn and let me heal them.”’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: You must understand that this message about God’s salvation has been sent to the gentiles, and they will listen.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: For two whole years Paul lived in his own rented place and welcomed everyone who came to him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He continued to preach about the kingdom of God and to teach boldly and freely about the Lord Jesus, the Messiah.
verses.speaker: Narrator
